name: Conscious Discipline
summary: A trauma-informed social-emotional learning program that integrates classroom management with emotional regulation strategies for children, parents, and educators.
description: Conscious Discipline, developed by Dr. Becky Bailey, is both a comprehensive classroom management program and a social-emotional learning framework. It focuses on building safety, connection, and problem-solving skills to promote self-regulation in children and adults. Conscious Discipline provides educators and parents with practical strategies to manage conflict, model emotional regulation, and foster cooperation, resilience, and empathy. It is widely applied in schools, early childhood programs, and family settings.

metadata.session_duration: Varies; classroom-based daily use, workshops 60–120 minutes

contraindications: Crisis environments requiring immediate safety measures
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Safe and non-invasive. Relies on educational/behavioral strategies.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Emerging—supported by school-based research and implementation studies, but fewer RCTs than traditional therapies.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Studies indicate improvement in classroom climate, reductions in behavioral incidents, and increased self-regulation skills.

sections.text: Conscious Discipline integrates emotional regulation, relationship-building, and behavioral management. It frames discipline as an opportunity to teach self-control rather than punish misbehavior. By fostering safety, connection, and problem-solving, children and adults learn to shift from reactive to proactive states and develop resilience.

sections.preparation: Educators and/or parents are trained in Conscious Discipline principles and practices.
procedure: Establishing routines and rituals to promote classroom safety and connection.
Teaching children skills for recognizing emotions, self-regulating, and solving problems.
Coaching adults in modeling calm, regulated responses.
Using structured conflict resolution and problem-solving strategies.
sections.frequency: Integrated into daily routines at school or home; workshops offered periodically.
sections.total_treatment_time: Embedded in classroom or parenting practices indefinitely.

sections.treatment_phase: Modeling of emotional regulation, interactive activities, and conflict resolution strategies.
sections.post_session: Reflection, feedback, and integration into daily life.

immediate: Increased adult awareness of emotional modeling
long_term: Enhanced school climate and family relationships

relative: Low implementation fidelity due to lack of buy-in

ideal_candidates: Schools or families seeking proactive behavioral support
Children with emotional or behavioral dysregulation
Educators aiming to build trauma-informed classrooms
screening_required: Readiness of educators and/or caregivers to implement strategies

practitioner: Educators, therapists, and parents trained in Conscious Discipline
facility: Schools, early childhood centers, family therapy settings

studies: Hoffman KT, Hutchinson CJ. (2017). The impact of Conscious Discipline on teacher efficacy and student behavior. Early Childhood Research & Practice.
Bailey BE. (2015). Conscious Discipline: Building Resilient Classrooms.
sections.limitations: Limited RCT data; more commonly studied through implementation studies in schools.

sections.cost_effectiveness: May reduce long-term costs associated with disruptive behavior and teacher burnout

lifestyle_recommendations: Daily rituals to reinforce safety and connection

sections.adhd: Can be adapted with visual aids and structured routines.
sections.trauma: Well-suited for trauma-informed classroom or family settings.
sections.preschool: Frequently implemented in early childhood education.
